Energy Efficient Federated Learning in Integrated Fog-Cloud Computing Enabled Internet-of-Things Networks

Mohammed S. Al-Abiad, Student Member, IEEE, Md. Zoheb Hassan, Student Member, IEEE, and Md. Jahangir Hossain, Senior Member, IEEE Mohammed S. Al-Abiad and Md. Jahangir Hossain are with the School of Engineering, University of British Columbia, Kelowna, BC V1V 1V7, Canada (e-mail: m.saif@alumni.ubc.ca, jahangir.hossain@ubc.ca). Md. Zoheb Hassan is with E´´E\acute{\text{E}}cole de technologie supe´´e\acute{\text{e}}rieure (ETS), University of Quebec, Canada (e-mail: md-zoheb.hassan.1@ens.etsmtl.ca).
Abstract

We investigate resource allocation scheme to reduce the energy consumption of federated learning (FL) in the integrated fog-cloud computing enabled Internet-of-things (IoT) networks. In the envisioned system, IoT devices are connected with the centralized cloud server (CS) via multiple fog access points (F-APs). We consider two different scenarios for training the local models. In the first scenario, local models are trained at the IoT devices and the F-APs upload the local model parameters to the CS. In the second scenario, local models are trained at the F-APs based on the collected data from the IoT devices and the F-APs collaborate with the CS for updating the model parameters. Our objective is to minimize the overall energy-consumption of both scenarios subject to FL time constraint. Towards this goal, we devise a joint optimization of scheduling of IoT devices with the F-APs, transmit power allocation, computation frequency allocation at the devices and F-APs and decouple it into two subproblems. In the first subproblem, we optimize the IoT device scheduling and power allocation, while in the second subproblem, we optimize the computation frequency allocation. For each scenario, we develop a conflict graph based solution to iteratively solve the two subproblems. Simulation results show that the proposed two schemes achieve a considerable performance gain in terms of the energy consumption minimization. The presented simulation results interestingly reveal that for a large number of IoT devices and large data sizes, it is more energy efficient to train the local models at the IoT devices instead of the F-APs.

Index Terms:
Computation frequency control, energy consumption, federated learning, fog computing, Internet of Things (IoT), power control, quality of service (QoS).

I Introduction

The emerging Internet-of-Things (IoT) leads to the unprecedented growth of the connected IoT devices in the wireless networks and significant rise of several computation demanding applications, such as interactive gaming, virtual/augmented reality, image/video processing. Cloud computing provides an efficient computation platform for executing the aforementioned applications. However, cloud computing requires efficient offloading of computation intensive tasks from the energy-constrained mobile devices to the cloud server (CS) of enormous computation capability [1]. In particular, the offloading of a task to a distant CS increases latency and security risk (e.g., important data should not be offloaded to CSs that are located outside a national territory) [2]. Hence, the benefit of cloud computing is diminished for the latency-sensitive and security critical applications [3]. Fog computing provides a complementary solution to the contemporary cloud computing by reducing the distance between the computing CS and mobile devices [4].

In fog computing systems, fog access points (F-APs), with certain storage and computation capabilities, are deployed at the network edge [6, 5, 7, 8]. As a result, mobile devices can offload the computation intensive tasks directly to the nearby F-APs instead of a distant CS, leading to the low-latency and fast access services. Moreover, an integration of fog and cloud computing provides a powerful computation and communication platform for the large number of IoT devices. Such an integrated architecture is referred as integrated fog-cloud computing (FCC)-enabled IoT system [9]. The integrated FCC provides powerful computation architecture for the IoT device, and it benefits from the centralized signal processing at the CS. Thereby, the integrated FCC can efficiently provide the required quality-of-service (QoS) for the emerging IoT applications.

Recently, the data driven decision making becomes an integral part of IoT networks, thanks to the availability of the enormous data and advancement of the devices’ computing power. In particular, machine learning algorithms are extensively used to predict traffic congestion, user behavior, and QoS of users by analyzing large-scale data collected from the IoT devices. In conventional ML, the collected data from IoT devices (e.g., images, videos, and recorded audios) are offloaded to and processed in the centralized CSs, where the learning models are trained. Such a centralized ML approach is confronted by the huge traffic burden in the wireless links between IoT devices and core network. In addition, the privacy of users’ sensitive data is impeded. Therefore, the conventional centralized learning method is inefficient for next generation IoT network [10]. Federated learning (FL) has been emerged as an efficient decentralized learning mechanism that allows multiple network edge devices to collaboratively learn a shared model [11]. In FL, the network edge devices train learning models locally based on local data. In contrast to the centralized learning mechanism, the devices only share updated model parameters with the CS. Subsequently, the CS calculates the global model parameter by aggregating local model updates from edge network. The local and global parameters are updated iteratively until convergence. By distributing the learning tasks between the network edge and centralized CSs, FL not only reduces the huge traffic burden over wireless channel, but also protects privacy of IoT data [12].

Due to the availability of distributed computing resources, an integrated FCC system provides a convenient platform to implement FL in wireless networks. In fact, using FL in integrated FCC system, the QoS of users can be significantly improved [13]. However, the channel impairments and interference present the key challenges to implement FL over wireless networks. Specifically, the FL training loss and convergence time jointly depends on selection of the collaborating devices, spectrum resource allocation, power allocation, and computation capability of the collaborating devices [14]. It is also imperative to reduce the energy consumption of the IoT devices participating in FL process. Particularly, IoT devices consume both communication and computation energy when the local models are trained at the IoT devices. To save the computation energy consumption, fog computing resources can be leveraged for local learning. However, in such a scenario, the communication energy consumption can be increased as the IoT devices need to upload a large amount of data to nearby F-APs with a strict latency constraint. To this end, we consider two different scenarios where the local models are trained either at the IoT devices or F-APs. For both scenarios, we develop resource allocation mechanisms to reduce energy consumption of FL with strict delay constraints.

I-A Related Works and Motivations

Related works on communication-efficient FL: The performance of a decentralized ML depends on the optimization of wireless links between the network edge devices and parameter server (CS or fog computing nodes). Hence, it is imperative to optimally design the learning-centric resource allocation schemes [15]. In the recent literature, the design of communication-efficient FL was extensively studied. Leveraging the grouping of network edge devices and a decentralized group alternating direction method of multipliers, a jointly communication efficient and fast converging FL algorithm was proposed in [16]. To enhance the accuracy and convergence of FL, it is imperative to enhance the number of collaborating edge devices while using the available spectrum resources efficiently. To this end, a collaborative FL framework was proposed that allows resource constrained IoT devices to upload model parameters to the nearby devices instead of the distance CS [17]. Moreover, a joint scheduling of network edge devices and radio resource blocks (RRBs) was studied to minimize the FL loss function via applying Lyapunov optimization framework [18]. In a heterogeneous cellular network, a hierarchical FL framework can effectively enhance the number of devices participating in local learning [19]. In such a hierarchical FL framework, at each round, the network edge devices upload their model parameters only to the nearest F-APs (therein called small base-stations), and F-APs periodically upload the average local model parameters to the CS (therein called macro base-station) for a global aggregation. Thus, a large number of devices can participate in local learning. Besides, interference among the network edge devices can induce error in FL and increase the convergence time. Accordingly, interference aware radio resource allocation is also imperative for communication-efficient FL framework. A joint optimization of user selection, RRB allocation, and transmit power allocation was presented to minimize the loss function in FL training process. The authors in [20] proposed transmit power allocation of the IoT devices to enhance information freshness in FL system. Considering the presence of eavesdroppers in an Internet-of-drones network, the authors in [21] proposed a secured and delay-constrained FL scheme through transmit power allocations.

Related works on energy-efficient FL: Since the mobile devices are battery-driven, for a sustainable operation of an FL framework, it is imperative to reduce energy consumption of the edge devices. In particular, an energy-efficient or green FL should consider minimizing communication and computation energy. In [22], energy-efficient radio resource allocation was proposed for delay constrained FL. However, the authors in [22] only minimized the communication energy and ignored the computation energy. In [23], the authors proposed an adaptive FL framework, where the devices can send quantized or compressed model parameters and thus, save energy. However, the radio resource optimization was not presented in [23]. In [24], radio resource allocation was developed to minimize both communication and computation energy in an FL system subject to delay constraints. However, the authors in [24] considered orthogonal multiple access (OMA) to connect edge devices with the base-station, which can limit the number of collaborating devices. Using OMA, the authors in [25] also proposed joint transmit power and computation frequency allocation to reduce overall energy consumption of FL in a fog-aided IoT network. The energy limitation of the collaborating edge devices can also be improved by energy-harvesting technique [26]. Moreover, the work in [27] considered a game theory framework to motivate the network edge devices to participate in local learning while reducing its energy consumption.

Motivations and Challenges: In contrast to the existing works [22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27], our motivation is to develop resource allocation mechanisms to facilitate energy-efficient FL in an integrated FCC-enabled IoT network. The considered architecture has a number of F-APs along with an CS, and the IoT devices are connected with the CS through F-APs. To improve the number of connected devices with F-APs using limited RRBs, an uplink non-OMA (NOMA) scheme [28] is considered. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that investigates efficient integration of joint cloud-fog computing and NOMA technique to reduce energy consumption of FL scheme. However, to take advantage of such an architecture for reducing energy consumption of FL, we need to develop a computationally efficient resource allocation scheme. Specifically, we need to address the following two challenges.

  • •

    Challenge I: In the first scenario, F-APs can work as relays where all the local learning is executed at the IoT devices. Alternatively, F-APs have the computation capability, and thus, they can participate in local learning along with the IoT devices. Therefore, in the second scenario, F-APs can work as local learning nodes to save the computation energy consumption of the connected IoT devices. Essentially, we need to investigate which of the aforementioned two scenarios has better energy-efficiency.

  • •

    Challenge II: There is an inherent trade-off between FL time and energy consumption. In particular, both computation and communication energy are increased to reduce the FL time. Accordingly, to satisfy a given FL time constraint and reduce energy consumption, it is imperative to jointly optimize the degrees-of-freedom, namely, power allocation, IoT device scheduling to the F-APs/RRBs, and computation frequency allocation. However, an interplay of the aforementioned factors leads to a high computational complexity. Essentially, we need to develop a computationally efficient resource allocation scheme to address the trade-off between FL time and energy consumption.

I-B Contributions

We investigate resource allocation for energy-efficient FL in an integrated FCC-enabled IoT network. Specifically, we propose a joint optimization of scheduling of IoT devices with the F-APs/RRBs, transmit power allocations, and computation frequency allocation at the IoT devices and F-APs. To this end, we introduce innovative graph-theoretical frameworks to develop computationally efficient solution. The main contributions of our work are as follows.

  1. 1.

    We consider two different scenarios for training the local model. In the first scenario, referred as IoT device local learning, local models are trained at the IoT devices and the F-APs upload the collected local model parameters to the CS for aggregation. In the second scenario, referred as F-AP local learning, the local models are trained at the F-APs based on the collected data from the IoT devices. For both scenarios, we aim at minimizing the overall energy consumption of IoT devices and F-APs subject to FL time constraint, IoT device-RRB/F-AP scheduling, transmit power allocations, and computation frequency allocation. Such a joint optimization problem is NP-hard and thus, computationally intractable. By analyzing the problem of each scenario, we decompose it into two subproblems namely, resource scheduling and power allocation subproblem and computation frequency allocation subproblem.

  2. 2.

    To solve the first subproblem, using graph theory, we design a low-complexity algorithm to optimize the scheduling among the IoT devices, F-APs, and RRBs. and transmit power levels of the IoT devices. In contrast, we obtain closed-form computation frequency allocation solution that depends on the scheduling obtained in the first subproblem. For both scenarios, efficient solutions are obtained by solving the aforementioned two subproblems alternately. The computational complexities of the proposed schemes are analyzed as well.

  3. 3.

    Extensive simulations are conducted to verify advantages of the proposed schemes over the benchmark schemes. Numerical results revealed that both proposed schemes offer improved energy consumption performances as compared to the benchmark schemes. The presented simulation results also interestingly reveal that for a large number of IoT devices and large data sizes, it is more energy efficient to train the local models at the IoT devices instead of the F-APs.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. The system model is described in Section II. The optimization problems for the considered scenarios are provided in Section III. In Section IV and Section V, we develop two graph theory schemes to facilitate local learning at the IoT devices and F-APs, respectively. Simulation results are presented in Section VI, and in Section VII, we conclude the paper.

II System Overview

II-A System Model

We consider an integrated FCC-enabled IoT system, illustrated in Fig. 1, that consists of one cloud server (CS), K𝐾K F-APs, and N𝑁N IoT devices. The sets of IoT devices and F-APs are denoted by 𝒩={1,2,⋯,N}𝒩12⋯𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\} and 𝒦={1,2,⋯,K}𝒦12⋯𝐾\mathcal{K}=\{1,2,\cdots,K\}, respectively. The N𝑁N IoT devices (e.g., smartphones, laptops, and cameras) are connected to the F-APs which are connected to the CS using fronthaul links. We consider that each F-AP has a limited coverage range that represents the service area of the k𝑘k-th F-AP within a circle of radius 𝚁𝚁\mathtt{R}. The set of IoT devices in the k𝑘k-th F-AP’s coverage range is defined by 𝒩k={n∈𝒩|dk,n≤𝚁\mathcal{N}_{k}=\{n\in\mathcal{N}|d_{k,n}\leq\mathtt{R}}, where dk,nsubscript𝑑𝑘𝑛d_{k,n} is the distance between the k𝑘k-th F-AP and the n𝑛n-th IoT device. Let 𝐀=ak,n𝐀subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛\mathbf{A}={a_{k,n}} be the F-AP allocation matrix, where element ak,n=1subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛1a_{k,n}=1 represents that the n𝑛n-th IoT device is allocated to the k𝑘k-th F-AP, and ak,n=0subscript𝑎𝑘𝑛0a_{k,n}=0 otherwise.

Let 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} denote the local data set of IoT device n𝑛n, which is a set of data samples {xi,yi}subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\{x_{i},y_{i}\}, where xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is sample i𝑖i’s input (e.g., image pixels) and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is sample i𝑖i’s output (e.g., label of the image). Similar to [23, 25], the local loss function on IoT device n𝑛n’s data set can be calculated as Ln​(ω)=1Dn​∑i∈𝒟nli​(ω),∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐿𝑛𝜔1subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝑙𝑖𝜔for-all𝑛𝒩L_{n}(\omega)=\frac{1}{D_{n}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}l_{i}(\omega),\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, where Dn=|𝒟n|subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛D_{n}=|\mathcal{D}_{n}| is the number of collected data samples by IoT device n𝑛n and li​(ω)subscript𝑙𝑖𝜔l_{i}(\omega) is the loss function that measures the local training model error of data sample i𝑖i. Then, IoT device n𝑛n finds the optimum ωn∗subscriptsuperscript𝜔𝑛\omega^{*}_{n} that minimizes Ln​(ω)subscript𝐿𝑛𝜔L_{n}(\omega) and uploads it to the suitable F-APs for aggregation by the CS. The IoT devices independently train local ML models based on their aggregated local data (e.g., images, videos, recorded audios). As shown in Fig. 1, the specific process of FL in the t𝑡t-th iteration can be summarized as: 1) each IoT device downloads the global model parameters ωn​(t−1)subscript𝜔𝑛𝑡1\omega_{n}(t-1) from the CS through the nearest F-AP; 2) each IoT device updates the local model by its local training data and sends the updated local model parameter ωn​(t)subscript𝜔𝑛𝑡\omega_{n}(t) back to the F-APs; and 3) the CS aggregates the information from the F-APs and calculates the new global model parameters.

Each IoT device uploads the local information to the nearest F-AP via a wireless link. Similar to the resource setting in [29, 30], we consider that each F-AP has Z𝑍Z orthogonal RRBs that are denoted by the set 𝒵={1,2,⋯,Z}𝒵12⋯𝑍\mathcal{Z}=\{1,2,\cdots,Z\}, where IoT devices can transmit their local information to the F-APs. These RRBs can be used practically as a generic term to denote time/frequency resource block of every F-AP, i.e., a group of orthogonal sub-carriers [5]. Let 𝐒={sk,zn}𝐒subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝑘𝑧\mathbf{S}=\{s^{n}_{k,z}\} be the RRB allocation matrix, where element sk,zn=1subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝑘𝑧1s^{n}_{k,z}=1 represents that the n𝑛n-th IoT device is allocated to the k𝑘k-th F-AP on the z𝑧z-th RRB, and sk,zn=0subscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝑘𝑧0s^{n}_{k,z}=0 otherwise. In this work, we consider a simple and efficient system’s design where the scheduling-level coordination takes place, i.e., each user is only scheduled to a single RRB [5, 29, 30]. To schedule number of IoT devices to each RRB, we consider NOMA. Let pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} denote the transmission power of the n𝑛n-th IoT device and let 𝐩𝐩\bf p be a 1×N1𝑁1\times N matrix containing the power levels of all IoT devices, i.e., p=[pn]pdelimited-[]subscript𝑝𝑛\textbf{p}=[p_{n}]. At the F-APs, each F-AP uploads its collected local parameters to the CS through a fronthaul link of capacity Rf​hsubscript𝑅𝑓ℎR_{fh}.

In this work, we consider two different scenarios for training the local models: i) IoT device local learning and ii) F-AP local learning that are explained as follows.

II-B IoT Device Local Learning Scenario

In this scenario, the role of IoT devices is to perform local training and upload the local parameters to the F-APs and to the CS. The F-APs is only responsible for forwarding the collected local parameters from the IoT devices to the CS. This scenario is illustrated in Fig. 2-(a) and divided into FL time and energy consumption as follows.

1) FL time: In each iteration, the FL time consists of the computation time for local model training and the transmission time for uploading local model parameters to the F-APs as well as to the CS. In the local training process, IoT device n𝑛n trains the local model and updates its local parameter until a local accuracy ϵlsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙\epsilon_{l} is achieved [23]. Let Cnsubscript𝐶𝑛C_{n} denote the number of CPU cycles to process one data sample of IoT device n𝑛n, and accordingly, the number of CPU cycles required for one local iteration over all data samples is Cn​Dnsubscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛C_{n}D_{n}. Therefore, the computation time for one local iteration in IoT device n𝑛n can be calculated as Cn​Dnfnsubscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛\frac{C_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}, where fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} is the computational speed of the CPU in IoT device n𝑛n (in cycles per second) [31]. Let fNsubscriptfN\textbf{f}_{\text{N}} be a 1×N1𝑁1\times N matrix containing the computation frequency allocations of all IoT devices, i.e., fN=[fn]subscriptf𝑁delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑛\textbf{f}_{N}=[f_{n}]. Then, the computation time of IoT device n𝑛n is expressed as

(3)

The learning time τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} should satisfy the QoS requirement. Specifically, τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1} should be no more than the maximum FL time Tqsubscript𝑇𝑞T_{q}, i.e., τ1≤Tqsubscript𝜏1subscript𝑇𝑞\tau_{1}\leq T_{q}. Hence, the QoS requirement can be expressed as

maxn∈𝒩⁡{Tl​Cn​Dnfn+dnRk,zn}+maxk∈𝒦⁡{∑n∈𝒩kdnRf​h}≤Tq,subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑧𝑛subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝑑𝑛subscript𝑅𝑓ℎsubscript𝑇𝑞\displaystyle\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\left\{T_{l}\frac{C_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}+\frac{d_{n}}{R_{k,z}^{n}}\right\}+\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\left\{\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}d_{n}}{R_{fh}}\right\}\leq T_{q}, (4)

and can be written as

Tl​Cn​Dnfn+dnRk,zn+∑n∈𝒩kdnRf​h≤Tq,∀n∈𝒩,∀k∈𝒦.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑧𝑛subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝑑𝑛subscript𝑅𝑓ℎsubscript𝑇𝑞formulae-sequencefor-all𝑛𝒩for-all𝑘𝒦\displaystyle T_{l}\frac{C_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}+\frac{d_{n}}{R_{k,z}^{n}}+\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}d_{n}}{R_{fh}}\leq T_{q},\forall n\in\mathcal{N},\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. (5)

2) Energy consumption model: The IoT device’s energy is consumed for both local model training and parameter transmission over wireless links that is explained as follows.

  • •

    Local computation: We adopt the widely used energy consumption model which considers that the energy consumption of IoT device n𝑛n to process a single CPU cycle is α​fn2𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑛\alpha f^{2}_{n}, where α𝛼\alpha is a constant related to the switched capacitance [33, 34]. Hence, the energy consumption of IoT device n𝑛n for local computation is Enc=Tl​Cn​Dn​α​fn2subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑛subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑛E^{c}_{n}=T_{l}C_{n}D_{n}\alpha f^{2}_{n} [21].

  • •

    Parameter transmission: The energy consumption to upload local model parameters to the F-APs over wireless links can be denoted by Enwsubscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑤𝑛E^{w}_{n} and calculated as pn​Tnwsubscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑤𝑛p_{n}T^{w}_{n}. Since the local parameters are forwarded from the F-APs to the CS over high transmission links, the energy consumption is negligible. Hence, we discard the F-APs’ energy consumption.

By combining all the aforementioned terms of energy consumption, the total energy consumption of the system in the IoT device local learning scenario can be calculated as

E=∑n∈𝒩(Enw+Enc)=∑n∈𝒩[pn​dnRk,zn+Tl​Cn​Dn​α​fn2].𝐸subscript𝑛𝒩subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑤𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝐸𝑐𝑛subscript𝑛𝒩delimited-[]subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑘𝑧subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑛\displaystyle E=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\left(E^{w}_{n}+E^{c}_{n}\right)=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\left[\frac{p_{n}d_{n}}{R^{n}_{k,z}}+T_{l}C_{n}D_{n}\alpha f^{2}_{n}\right]. (6)

II-C F-AP Local Learning Scenario

The IoT devices, in this scenario, are solely responsible for uploading their data to the F-APs. The F-APs, then, train local models using these collected data and upload the resulting local parameters to the CS for global aggregation. This scenario is illustrated in Fig. 2-(b). The FL time and energy consumption of this scenario are explained as follows.

1) FL time: In each iteration, the FL time consists of the transmission time for uploading the data from IoT devices to F-APs, the computation time for training local models at the F-APs, and the transmission time for uploading the resulting local model parameters to the CS. Consider that the data size 𝙳nsubscript𝙳𝑛\mathtt{D}_{n} of the uploaded data 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} by IoT device n∈𝒩k𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘n\in\mathcal{N}_{k} is fixed over the learning process [32]. The transmission time for uploading data from IoT devices 𝒩ksubscript𝒩𝑘\mathcal{N}_{k} to F-AP k𝑘k is written as

Tkw=maxn∈𝒩k⁡{𝙳nRk,zn},∀z∈𝒵.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑤𝑘subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝙳𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑧𝑛for-all𝑧𝒵T^{w}_{k}=\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\left\{\frac{\mathtt{D}_{n}}{R_{k,z}^{n}}\right\},\forall z\in\mathcal{Z}. (7)

Each F-AP k𝑘k iteratively trains the local learning model on the collected data and updates its local parameter ωk​(t)subscript𝜔𝑘𝑡\omega_{k}(t) until a local accuracy ϵlsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙\epsilon_{l} is achieved. Let Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} denote the number of CPU cycles to process one data sample of F-AP k𝑘k. Hence, the number of CPU cycles required for one local iteration is Ck​Bksubscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘C_{k}B_{k}, where Bksubscript𝐵𝑘B_{k} is the number of uploaded data samples ℬksubscriptℬ𝑘\mathcal{B}_{k} to F-AP k𝑘k, i.e., Bk=|ℬk|subscript𝐵𝑘subscriptℬ𝑘B_{k}=|\mathcal{B}_{k}| and ℬk=∪n∈𝒩k𝒟nsubscriptℬ𝑘subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{B}_{k}=\cup_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\mathcal{D}_{n}. Therefore, the computation time for one local iteration at F-AP k𝑘k can be calculated as Ck​Bkfksubscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘\frac{C_{k}B_{k}}{f_{k}}, where fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} is the computational speed of the CPU in F-AP k𝑘k (in cycles per second). Let fKsubscriptfK\textbf{f}_{\text{K}} be a 1×K1𝐾1\times K matrix containing the computation frequency allocations of all F-APs, i.e., fK=[fk]subscriptf𝐾delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑘\textbf{f}_{K}=[f_{k}]. Consider that the number of local iterations of F-APs to reach the local accuracy ϵlsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙\epsilon_{l} is Tlsubscript𝑇𝑙T_{l}. Then, the computation time of F-AP k𝑘k is expressed as

Tkc=Tl​Ck​Bkfk.subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝑐𝑘subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘T^{c}_{k}=T_{l}\frac{C_{k}B_{k}}{f_{k}}. (8)

Since the global model parameters can only be updated after all local model parameters are received from the F-APs, the FL time τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} in each global iteration is determined by the longest time for uploading data to F-APs, training local models at the F-APs, and the longest time for transmitting the parameters from the F-APs to the CS. Thus, the learning time τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} of one global iteration can be calculated as

τ2subscript𝜏2\displaystyle\tau_{2} =maxk∈𝒦⁡{Tkw+Tkc+Tk}absentsubscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑘𝑐subscript𝑇𝑘\displaystyle=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\{T_{k}^{w}+T_{k}^{c}+T_{k}\}
=maxk∈𝒦⁡{maxn∈𝒩k⁡{𝙳nRk,zn}+Tl​Ck​Bkfk+dkRf​h},absentsubscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝙳𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑧𝑛subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑅𝑓ℎ\displaystyle=\max_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\left\{\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}\left\{\frac{\mathtt{D}_{n}}{R_{k,z}^{n}}\right\}+T_{l}\frac{C_{k}B_{k}}{f_{k}}+\frac{d_{k}}{R_{fh}}\right\}, (9)

where dksubscript𝑑𝑘d_{k} is the local parameter size of F-AP k𝑘k. Similar to the first scenario, the learning time τ2subscript𝜏2\tau_{2} should satisfy the QoS requirement, i.e., τ2≤Tqsubscript𝜏2subscript𝑇𝑞\tau_{2}\leq T_{q}. Thus, the QoS requirement can be expressed as

and can be written per F-AP as

(11)

2) Energy consumption model: The IoT device’s energy is consumed for data transmission over wireless links, which is Enw=pn​Tnw=pn​𝙳nRk,znsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛𝑤subscript𝑝𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛𝑤subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝙳𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑧𝑛E_{n}^{w}=p_{n}T_{n}^{w}=\frac{p_{n}\mathtt{D}_{n}}{R_{k,z}^{n}}. For the F-APs, the energy consumption is explained as follows.

  • •

    Local computation: The energy consumption model of F-AP k𝑘k for processing a single CPU cycle is α​fk2𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑘\alpha f^{2}_{k}. (12)

III Problem Formulation

We propose to minimize the total energy consumption for a delay-constrained FL. Specifically, our proposed framework intelligently selects the active IoT devices that perform local learning and assigns active IoT devices to the suitable F-APs. Considering IoT device local learning scenario, the energy minimization problem can be formulated as

𝒫1:min𝐀,𝐒,fN,𝐩​∑n∈𝒩[pn​dnRk,zn+Tl​Cn​Dn​α​fn2]:subscript𝒫1subscript𝐀𝐒subscriptf𝑁𝐩subscript𝑛𝒩delimited-[]subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑘𝑧subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑛\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{1}:\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{A},\mathbf{S},\textbf{f}_{N},\mathbf{p}\end{subarray}}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\left[\frac{p_{n}d_{n}}{R^{n}_{k,z}}+T_{l}C_{n}D_{n}\alpha f^{2}_{n}\right]
s.t.{C1:​∑k∈𝒦ak,n=1&∑z∈𝒵sk,zn=1,∀n∈𝒩,C2:​∑n∈𝒩sk,zn≤2,∀k∈𝒦,z∈𝒵;C3:​fnmin≤fn≤fnmax,∀n∈𝒩,C4:​τ1≤Tq;C5:​0≤pn≤pmax,∀n∈𝒩;C6:​ai,j∈{0,1},si,jk∈{0,1}.formulae-sequencestcasesformulae-sequenceC1:subscriptk𝒦subscriptakn1subscriptz𝒵subscriptsuperscriptsnkz1for-alln𝒩otherwiseformulae-sequenceC2:subscriptn𝒩subscriptsuperscriptsnkz2formulae-sequencefor-allk𝒦z𝒵otherwiseformulae-sequenceC3:subscriptsuperscriptfnsubscriptfnsubscriptsuperscriptfnfor-alln𝒩otherwiseC4:subscript𝜏1subscriptTqotherwiseformulae-sequenceC5:0subscriptpnsubscriptpfor-alln𝒩otherwiseformulae-sequenceC6:subscriptaij01subscriptsuperscriptskij01otherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C1:}\hskip 5.69046pt\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}a_{k,n}=1~{}\&~{}\sum_{z\in\mathcal{Z}}s^{n}_{k,z}=1,\forall n\in\mathcal{N},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C2:}\hskip 5.69046pt\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}s^{n}_{k,z}\leq 2,\forall k\in\mathcal{K},z\in\mathcal{Z};\hskip 5.69046pt\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C3:}\hskip 5.69046ptf^{\min}_{n}\leq f_{n}\leq f^{\max}_{n},~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C4:}\hskip 5.69046pt\tau_{1}\leq T_{q};\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C5:}\hskip 5.69046pt0\leq p_{n}\leq p_{\max},~{}\forall n\in\mathcal{N};\hskip 5.69046pt\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C6:}\hskip 5.69046pta_{i,j}\in\{0,1\},s^{k}_{i,j}\in\{0,1\}.\end{cases}

In 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}, C1 indicates that each IoT device is scheduled to only one F-AP and to only one RRB in that F-AP; C2 indicates that maximum two IoT devices can be scheduled to each F-AP at the same time; C3 is the constraint on local computation resource allocations of IoT devices; C4 indicates the QoS requirement on the FL time; and C5 is the transmit power control constraint.

The optimization problem of energy consumption minimization for FL integrated FCC-enabled IoT networks of the F-AP local learning scenario can be expressed as

𝒫2:min𝐀,𝐒,fK,𝐩​∑n∈𝒩[pn​𝙳nRk,zn]+∑k∈𝒦[Tl​Ck​Bk​α​fk2+qk​dkRf​h]:subscript𝒫2subscript𝐀𝐒subscriptf𝐾𝐩subscript𝑛𝒩delimited-[]subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝙳𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑘𝑧subscript𝑘𝒦delimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑘subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑑𝑘subscript𝑅𝑓ℎ\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{2}:\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{A},\mathbf{S},\textbf{f}_{K},\bf p\end{subarray}}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\left[\frac{p_{n}\mathtt{D}_{n}}{R^{n}_{k,z}}\right]+\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\left[T_{l}C_{k}B_{k}\alpha f^{2}_{k}+\frac{q_{k}d_{k}}{R_{fh}}\right]
s.t.{C1,C2,C5,C6,C3:​fkmin≤fk≤fkmax,∀k∈𝒦,C4:​𝙽k≤U,∀k∈𝒦;C7:​τ2≤Tq.formulae-sequencestcasesC1C2C5C6otherwiseformulae-sequenceC3:subscriptsuperscriptfksubscriptfksubscriptsuperscriptfkfor-allk𝒦otherwiseformulae-sequenceC4:subscript𝙽kUfor-allk𝒦otherwiseC7:subscript𝜏2subscriptTqotherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C1},\text{C2},\text{C5},\text{C6},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C3:}\hskip 5.69046ptf^{\min}_{k}\leq f_{k}\leq f^{\max}_{k},~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C4:}\hskip 5.69046pt\mathtt{N}_{k}\leq U,~{}\forall k\in\mathcal{K};\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C7:}\hskip 5.69046pt\tau_{2}\leq T_{q}.\end{cases}

In 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}, C3 is the constraint on local computation resource allocations of F-APs; C4 represents that the number of scheduled IoT devices to F-AP k𝑘k 𝙽ksubscript𝙽𝑘\mathtt{N}_{k} is less than or equal to the maximum number of scheduled IoT devices U𝑈U. This is becasue each F-AP has certain computation frequency capability, and thus it can schedule only a limited number of IoT devices. Finally, C5 indicates the QoS requirement on the FL time. Note that both problems 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} and 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} are non-convex optimization problems. In addition, owing to the coupling of the optimization variables fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}, fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} and pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n}, it is challenging to solve problems 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} and 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2}. To this end, we divide both optimization problems into two subproblems and optimize them iteratively in order to achieve suboptimal yet practical solutions.

IV Energy Consumption Minimization: First Scenario

IV-A Problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} Transformation

Solving problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} owing to its mixed combinatorial characteristics is challenging. Although exhaustive search and branch-and-bound approaches can obtain near-optimal solution to 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}, such approaches are not suitable for the practical systems due to the significantly increased computational complexity. To strike a suitable balance between the required complexity and performance, we propose an iterative approach to solve problem P1 for large-scale IoT networks. To this end, we decompose 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} into the following two subproblems, namely, (i) IoT device scheduling and power allocation subproblem for a given IoT device’ computation frequency allocation, and (ii) IoT device’ computation frequency allocation subproblem for the determined power and IoT device scheduling.

IoT Device Scheduling and Power Allocation Subproblem: For a fixed set of computation frequency allocation, fn∗,∀n∈𝒩subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩f^{*}_{n},\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, the optimization problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} can be written as

𝒫3:min𝐀,𝐒,𝐩​∑n∈𝒩pn​dnW​log2⁡(1+γk,zn):subscript𝒫3subscript𝐀𝐒𝐩subscript𝑛𝒩subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛𝑊subscript21subscriptsuperscript𝛾𝑛𝑘𝑧\displaystyle\mathcal{P}_{3}:\min_{\begin{subarray}{c}\mathbf{A},\mathbf{S},\bf p\end{subarray}}\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{p_{n}d_{n}}{W\log_{2}(1+\gamma^{n}_{k,z})}
s.t.{C1,C2,C5,C4:​Tl​Cn​Dnfn∗+dnRk,zn≤Tq,k,∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequencestcasesC1C2C5otherwiseformulae-sequenceC4:subscriptTlsubscriptCnsubscriptDnsubscriptsuperscriptfnsubscriptdnsuperscriptsubscriptRkznsubscriptTqkfor-alln𝒩otherwise\displaystyle\rm s.t.\begin{cases}\hskip 5.69046pt\text{C1},\text{C2},\text{C5},\\ \hskip 5.69046pt\text{C4:}\hskip 5.69046ptT_{l}\frac{C_{n}D_{n}}{f^{*}_{n}}+\frac{d_{n}}{R_{k,z}^{n}}\leq T_{q,k},\forall n\in\mathcal{N},\end{cases}

where Tq,k=Tq−∑n∈𝒩kdnRf​hsubscript𝑇𝑞𝑘subscript𝑇𝑞subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑘subscript𝑑𝑛subscript𝑅𝑓ℎT_{q,k}=T_{q}-\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{k}}d_{n}}{R_{fh}}. In 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3}, the optimization is over the continuous variables 𝐩𝐩\bf p, and the discrete variables ak,nsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑛a_{k,n}, and sk,zn,∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩,z∈𝒵formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝑘𝑧for-all𝑘𝒦formulae-sequence𝑛𝒩𝑧𝒵s^{n}_{k,z},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N},z\in\mathcal{Z}. Nevertheless, it is still challenging to solve problem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} because of the non-convexity. We hence design an efficient yet low-complexity graph theory algorithm to tackle this problem in Section IV. B.

𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is solved by iteratively solving both subproblems 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} and 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} until convergence. The overall algorithm to obtain a suitable solution to problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is provided in Section IV-C.

IV-B Subproblem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} Solution

In this subsection, we develop an effective and low complexity approach to solve the joint IoT device scheduling and power control subproblem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3}. Our developed solution designs a graph for all IoT device-RRB-F-AP feasible schedules and efficiently allocates power levels for the IoT devices in each schedule. The two-stage solution is explained as follows.

Stage 1: IoT Device Feasible Scheduling: In this stage, we design a graph that judiciously generates feasible NOMA clusters and jointly optimizes IoT devices-F-APs/RRBs assignments and transmit power of the IoT devices. This stage consists of graph design and maximum weight independent search (MWIS) method.

1) Graph design: Let 𝒢=(𝒱,ℰ,𝒲)𝒢𝒱ℰ𝒲\mathcal{G}=(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E},\mathcal{W}) represents an undirected graph. The graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is constructed by generating a vertex v𝑣v for each 2-IoT devices, RRB, and F-AP in the network as follows. We start from RRB z=1𝑧1z=1, and assume that IoT device n=1𝑛1n=1 is allocated to it. Then, we find the available NOMA clusters according to the possible two scenarios:

  1. 1.

    If IoT device n=1𝑛1n=1 is not in the service area of the k𝑘k-th F-AP, we check IoT device n=2𝑛2n=2 for possible association to RRB z𝑧z and F-AP k𝑘k, and then continue finding the second IoT device.

  2. 2.

    If IoT device n=1𝑛1n=1 is in the service area of the k𝑘k-th F-AP, then we find the second UD j=n+1𝑗𝑛1j=n+1 (currently, j=2𝑗2j=2), for the (n=1,z=1formulae-sequence𝑛1𝑧1n=1,z=1) pair. Afterwords, we find pn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑛p^{*}_{n}, pj∗subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑗p^{*}_{j} and calculate the rates, and then, we generate a vertex v={(rn∗,z,k),(rj∗,z,k)}𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑛𝑧𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑗𝑧𝑘v=\{(r^{*}_{n},z,k),(r^{*}_{j},z,k)\} that represents a feasible NOMA cluster. Given rn∗subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑛r^{*}_{n}, rj∗subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑗r^{*}_{j}, we then compute the weight of that vertex w​(v)=Xn+Xj𝑤𝑣subscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑋𝑗w(v)=X_{n}+X_{j} and update 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. If adding j=2𝑗2j=2 is infeasible, we let j=j+1=3𝑗𝑗13j=j+1=3, and we verify the feasibility and repeat the aforementioned step.

In order to obtain all the feasible NOMA clusters ((n,j)∈𝒩,z∈𝒵,k∈𝒦),j>nformulae-sequence𝑛𝑗𝒩formulae-sequence𝑧𝒵𝑘𝒦𝑗𝑛((n,j)\in\mathcal{N},z\in\mathcal{Z},k\in\mathcal{K}),j>n, we iteratively repeat the above process (1), (2). The vertices in the designed grpah 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} that represent NOMA feasible clusters are connected by a conflict edge according to the following connectivity conditions (CCs):

  • •

    CC1: The same IoT devices (any IoT device or both IoT devices) are associated with both vertices v𝑣v and v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime}.

  • •

    CC2: The same RRB in the same F-AP is associated with both vertices v𝑣v and v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime}.

In summary, two distinct vertices v𝑣v and v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime} representing two different NOMA clusters are connecting by a conflict edge if and only if the associations of RRBs and IoT devices (one or both associations) they represent are appeared in both vertices.

To select the IoT device-RRB-F-AP scheduling that provides a local minimum energy consumption, we design a proper weight w​(v)𝑤𝑣w(v) to each vertex v∈𝒢𝑣𝒢v\in\mathcal{G}. For notation simplicity, we define the utility of IoT devices n𝑛n and j𝑗j as Xn=Tl​Cn​Dn​α​fn2+pn​dnRk,znsubscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑘𝑧X_{n}=T_{l}C_{n}D_{n}\alpha f^{2}_{n}+\frac{p_{n}d_{n}}{R^{n}_{k,z}}, Xj=Tl​Cj​Dj​α​fj2+pj​djRk,zjsubscript𝑋𝑗subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑗subscript𝐷𝑗𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑗subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝑑𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑗𝑘𝑧X_{j}=T_{l}C_{j}D_{j}\alpha f^{2}_{j}+\frac{p_{j}d_{j}}{R^{j}_{k,z}}, respectively. Therefore, the weight of vertex v𝑣v that reflects the minimum energy consumption of IoT devices n,j𝑛𝑗n,j can be given by

w​(v)=Xnv+Xjv,𝑤𝑣subscript𝑋superscript𝑛𝑣subscript𝑋superscript𝑗𝑣w(v)=X_{n^{v}}+X_{j^{v}}, (19)

where Xnvsubscript𝑋superscript𝑛𝑣X_{n^{v}} and Xjvsubscript𝑋superscript𝑗𝑣X_{j^{v}} are the utility of associated IoT devices n𝑛n and j𝑗j to vertex v𝑣v, respectively. The weight of vertex v𝑣v in (19) is determined by the transmit powers {pn∗\{p^{*}_{n}, pj∗}p^{*}_{j}\}, computation frequency allocation {fn∗\{f^{*}_{n}, fj∗}f^{*}_{j}\}, RRB zvsuperscript𝑧𝑣z^{v}, and F-AP kvsuperscript𝑘𝑣k^{v} allocated to them.

2) MWIS search method: In this step, the algorithm itratively and greedily selects the MWIS Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} among all the minimal independent sets ΓΓ\Gamma in the graph 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, where in each iteration we implement the following procedures. We compute the weight of all generated vertices using (19). The vertex with the minimum weight v∗superscript𝑣v^{*} is selected among all other corresponding vertices. The selected vertex v∗superscript𝑣v^{*} is, then, added to Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} that is initially empty. Afterwards, we update the 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} graph by removing the selected vertices v∗superscript𝑣v^{*} and its connected vertices. As such, the next selected vertex is not in conflict connection with the already selected vertices in Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*}. The process continues until no more vertices exist in 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. Since each RRB in each F-AP contributes by a single vertex, the number of vertices in Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} is Z​K𝑍𝐾ZK.

Stage 2: Power Allocation: From the designed 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, we obtain a set of vertices that represent NOMA clusters. Each NOMA cluster includes two IoT devices that simultaneously transmit to an F-AP over an RRB. For each vertex, we aim to determine transmit power allocations of the IoT devices such that (i) the overall uplink transmission rate is improved by suppressing the interference between the IoT devices and (ii) the energy consumption for wireless transmission is reduced. Without loss of generality, we consider a vertex where the n𝑛n-th and the j𝑗j-th IoT devices are clustered, and both IoT devices transmit to the k𝑘k-th F-AP over the z𝑧z-th RRB. For such a vertex, we formulate the transmit power allocation subproblem as 𝒫3−1subscript𝒫31\mathcal{P}_{3}-1 at the top of the next page.

In subproblem 𝒫3−1subscript𝒫31\mathcal{P}_{3}-1, Rt​h,nsubscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑛R_{th,n} and Rt​h,jsubscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑗R_{th,j} are the required uplink data rates for the n𝑛n-th and j𝑗j-th IoT devices, respectively; and V𝑉V is a given weight factor. In particular, Rt​h,n=Tg​dnTq,k−Tg​Tl​Cn​Dnfn∗subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑛subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑑𝑛subscript𝑇𝑞𝑘subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛R_{th,n}=\frac{T_{g}d_{n}}{T_{q,k}-T_{g}T_{l}\frac{C_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}^{*}}} and Rt​h,j=Tg​djTq,k−Tg​Tl​Cj​Djfj∗subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑗subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑇𝑞𝑘subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑗subscript𝐷𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑗R_{th,j}=\frac{T_{g}d_{j}}{T_{q,k}-T_{g}T_{l}\frac{C_{j}D_{j}}{f_{j}^{*}}}. Essentially, the rate constraints C8 and C9 satisfy the FL delay constraint C4. On the other hand, the weight factor V𝑉V is selected to strike a suitable balance between capacity and energy consumption of the vertices.

Note that the power allocation depends on the channel gain of the associated IoT devices. To this end, we first define Δn=σ2pmax​(2Rt​h,n/W−1)subscriptΔ𝑛superscript𝜎2subscript𝑝superscript2subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑛𝑊1\Delta_{n}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{p_{\max}}\left(2^{R_{th,n}/W}-1\right) and Δj=σ2pmax​(2Rt​h,j/W−1)subscriptΔ𝑗superscript𝜎2subscript𝑝superscript2subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑗𝑊1\Delta_{j}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{p_{\max}}\left(2^{R_{th,j}/W}-1\right). Thereafter, we consider the following four cases: Case I: |Gk,zn|2<Δnsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑛2subscriptΔ𝑛\left|G_{k,z}^{n}\right|^{2}<\Delta_{n} and |Gk,zj|2<Δjsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑗2subscriptΔ𝑗\left|G_{k,z}^{j}\right|^{2}<\Delta_{j}, Case II: |Gk,zn|2≥Δnsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑛2subscriptΔ𝑛\left|G_{k,z}^{n}\right|^{2}\geq\Delta_{n} and |Gk,zj|2<Δjsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑗2subscriptΔ𝑗\left|G_{k,z}^{j}\right|^{2}<\Delta_{j}, Case III: |Gk,zn|2<Δnsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑛2subscriptΔ𝑛\left|G_{k,z}^{n}\right|^{2}<\Delta_{n} and |Gk,zj|2≥Δjsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑗2subscriptΔ𝑗\left|G_{k,z}^{j}\right|^{2}\geq\Delta_{j}, and Case IV: |Gk,zn|2≥Δnsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑛2subscriptΔ𝑛\left|G_{k,z}^{n}\right|^{2}\geq\Delta_{n} and |Gk,zj|2≥Δjsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑗2subscriptΔ𝑗\left|G_{k,z}^{j}\right|^{2}\geq\Delta_{j}. The transmit power allocations, (pn∗,pj∗)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗(p_{n}^{*},p_{j}^{*}), for each case are given as follows

Case I: In this case, both IoT devices can not satisfy the rate constraints even using the maximum transmit power. Consequently, both IoT devices suspend their data transmission, and we obtain pn∗=0superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛0p_{n}^{*}=0 and pj∗=0superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗0p_{j}^{*}=0.

Case II: In this case, only the n𝑛n-th IoT device can satisfy the required rate constraint, and the transmission of the j𝑗j-th IoT device is suspended. Therefore, we obtain pj∗=0superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗0p_{j}^{*}=0 and pn∗=σ2|Gk,zn|2​(2Rt​h,j/W−1)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛superscript𝜎2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑛2superscript2subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑗𝑊1p_{n}^{*}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{|G_{k,z}^{n}|^{2}}\left(2^{R_{th,j}/W}-1\right).

Case III: In this case, only the j𝑗j-th IoT device can satisfy the required rate constraint, and the transmission of the n𝑛n-th IoT device is suspended. Therefore, we obtain pn∗=0superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛0p_{n}^{*}=0 and pj∗=σ2|Gk,zj|2​(2Rt​h,j/W−1)superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗superscript𝜎2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑗2superscript2subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑗𝑊1p_{j}^{*}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{|G_{k,z}^{j}|^{2}}\left(2^{R_{th,j}/W}-1\right).

Case IV: In this case, both IoT devices can simultaneously transmit. Without loss of generality, we assume that |Gk,zj|2<|Gk,zn|2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑗2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑛2|G_{k,z}^{j}|^{2}<|G_{k,z}^{n}|^{2}, i.e., the n𝑛n-th IoT device has a better channel gain compared to the j𝑗j-th IoT device. According to the NOMA principle, the k𝑘k-th F-AP first decodes the n𝑛n-th IoT device’s signal, and subsequently, decodes the j𝑗j-th IoT device’s signal after removing the interference from the n𝑛n-th device via applying the SIC technique. We first introduce the following lemma to update the j𝑗j-th IoT device’s power allocation

Lemma 2: Assume that the given transmit power allocations for the n𝑛n-th and the j𝑗j-th IoT devices are p~nsubscript~𝑝𝑛\tilde{p}_{n} and p~jsubscript~𝑝𝑗\tilde{p}_{j}, respectively. Therefore, the j𝑗j-th IoT device’s transmit power allocation to maximize subproblem 𝒫3−1subscript𝒫31\mathcal{P}_{3}-1 is obtained as

pj=[γk,zj1+γk,zjV+(γk,zn)21+γk,zn​|Gk,zj|2p~n​|Gk,zn|2]pt​hpmaxsubscript𝑝𝑗superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑧𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑧𝑗𝑉superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑧𝑛21superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑧𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑗2subscript~𝑝𝑛superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐺𝑘𝑧𝑛2subscript𝑝𝑡ℎsubscript𝑝p_{j}=\left[\frac{\frac{\gamma_{k,z}^{j}}{1+\gamma_{k,z}^{j}}}{V+\frac{(\gamma_{k,z}^{n})^{2}}{1+\gamma_{k,z}^{n}}\frac{|G_{k,z}^{j}|^{2}}{\tilde{p}_{n}|G_{k,z}^{n}|^{2}}}\right]_{p_{th}}^{p_{\max}} (20)

Proof.

The proof is omitted due to the space limitation.

We consider a suboptimal approach to iteratively update the transmit power allocation of both the n𝑛n-th and the j𝑗j-th IoT devices in inner and outer loop. Specifically, using a bi-section search method, the outer loop adjusts the power allocation of the n𝑛n-th IoT device such that the rate constraint C8 is satisfied, and the inner loop adjusts the power allocation of the j𝑗j-th IoT device according to Lemma 2. Let us denote the minimum and maximum power level for the n𝑛n-th IoT device as pn,l​o​wsubscript𝑝𝑛𝑙𝑜𝑤p_{n,low} and pn,h​i​g​hsubscript𝑝𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑔ℎp_{n,high}. The initial transmit power of the n𝑛n-th IoT device is obtained as pn=pn,l​o​w+pn,h​i​g​h2subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛𝑙𝑜𝑤subscript𝑝𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑔ℎ2p_{n}=\frac{p_{n,low}+p_{n,high}}{2}. By plugging the transmit power of the n𝑛n-th IoT device to Lemma 2, the j𝑗j-th IoT device’s transmit power is determined. Thereafter, the achievable rate of the n𝑛n-th IoT device is calculated. If W​log2⁡(1+γk,zn)>Rt​h,1𝑊subscript21superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑧𝑛subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ1W\log_{2}(1+\gamma_{k,z}^{n})>R_{th,1}, pn,h​i​g​h←pn←subscript𝑝𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑔ℎsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n,high}\leftarrow p_{n} is applied and if W​log2⁡(1+γk,zn)<Rt​h,1𝑊subscript21superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑧𝑛subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ1W\log_{2}(1+\gamma_{k,z}^{n})<R_{th,1}, pn,l​o​w←pn←subscript𝑝𝑛𝑙𝑜𝑤subscript𝑝𝑛p_{n,low}\leftarrow p_{n} is applied. Then, the transmit power of the n𝑛n-th IoT device is updated as pn=pn,l​o​w+pn,h​i​g​h2subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛𝑙𝑜𝑤subscript𝑝𝑛ℎ𝑖𝑔ℎ2p_{n}=\frac{p_{n,low}+p_{n,high}}{2}. The aforementioned procedures are repeated until |W​log2⁡(1+γk,zn)−Rt​h,1|𝑊subscript21superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑧𝑛subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ1\left|W\log_{2}(1+\gamma_{k,z}^{n})-R_{th,1}\right| approaches a small value. The final values of pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} and pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j} provide the required power allocations for the Case IV. The overall two-stage algorithm to the subproblem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} is summarized in Algorithm 1.

IV-C Proposed Algorithm

Our proposed iterative scenario to the problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is summarized in Algorithm 2. Line 4 initiates the computation frequency allocation. The loop in lines 5-9 alternatively obtains the solutions of subproblems 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} and 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} and terminates when fn(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑡𝑛f^{(t)}_{n} does not change or the maximum number of iteration is reached. Specifically, line 666 calculates pn(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑛p^{(t)}_{n} with fixed fn(t−1)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑡1𝑛f^{(t-1)}_{n} from the previous iteration and line 777 calculates fn(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑡𝑛f^{(t)}_{n} with fixed pn(t)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑛p^{(t)}_{n} from the current iteration.

IV-D Complexity Analysis

The computational complexity of Algorithm 2 is dominated by the required complexity of the graph construction stage of Algorithm 1. In order to generate all the vertices using the low-complexity graph punning method, a total of 𝒪​(N​K​Z)𝒪𝑁𝐾𝑍\mathcal{O}(NKZ) computational complexity is required. The required complexity of connecting the generated vertices, i.e., the required complexity of finding neighborhood of the generated vertices is 𝒪​((N​K​Z)2)𝒪superscript𝑁𝐾𝑍2\mathcal{O}((NKZ)^{2}). Therefore, the overall computational complexity of Algorithm 2 is obtained as 𝒪​(N​K​Z+(N​K​Z)2)≈𝒪​(N2​K2​Z2)𝒪𝑁𝐾𝑍superscript𝑁𝐾𝑍2𝒪superscript𝑁2superscript𝐾2superscript𝑍2\mathcal{O}\left(NKZ+(NKZ)^{2}\right)\approx\mathcal{O}(N^{2}K^{2}Z^{2}).

Note that solving the power allocation problem 𝒫10subscript𝒫10\mathcal{P}_{10} for the resulting IoT device-RRB/F-AP schedule is omitted in this section becasue it can follow the solution of 𝒫3−1subscript𝒫31\mathcal{P}_{3}-1 in Section IV-B.

The graph-based solution of the IoT coordinated scheduling problem 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9} is explained as follows.

1) IoT Device Coordinated Scheduling: The NOMA-coordinated graph is introduced to jointly consider NOMA cluster per RRB, maximum number of IoT devices scheduled to F-AP, and transmission conflict. The NOMA-coordinated graph, denoted by 𝒢NOMA​(𝒱,ℰ)subscript𝒢NOMA𝒱ℰ\mathcal{G}_{\text{NOMA}}(\mathcal{V},\mathcal{E}), is designed by generating all vertices for the k𝑘k-th F-AP. The vertex set 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} of the entire graph is the union of vertices of all F-APs. Consider, for now, generating the vertices of F-AP k𝑘k. Therefore, each vertex vk,z,n,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑧𝑛𝑗v_{k,z,n,j} is generated for each z∈𝒵𝑧𝒵z\in\mathcal{Z} and for every 2-IoT devices (n,j)𝑛𝑗(n,j) in the service area of F-AP k𝑘k. Similarly, we generate all vertices for all F-APs in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}. The configuration of the set of edges in the NOMA-coordinated graph is divided into IoT devices’ association and transmission conflict edges. Two vertices vk,z,n,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑧𝑛𝑗v_{k,z,n,j} and vk,z′,n′,j′v_{k,z^{\prime},n^{\prime},j\prime} representing different RRB z𝑧z and the same F-AP k𝑘k are adjacent by a conflict link if the number of scheduled IoT devices 𝙽ksubscript𝙽𝑘\mathtt{N}_{k} to F-AP k𝑘k is more than U𝑈U. Similarly, two vertices vk,z,n,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑧𝑛𝑗v_{k,z,n,j} and vk′,z′,n′,j′subscript𝑣superscript𝑘′superscript𝑧′superscript𝑛′superscript𝑗′v_{k^{\prime},z^{\prime},n^{\prime},j^{\prime}} are adjacent by a transmission conflict link if one of these conditions is true:

  • •

    n=n′𝑛superscript𝑛′n=n^{\prime} and/or j=j′𝑗superscript𝑗′j=j^{\prime}. This condition schedules different IoT devices to different RRBs/F-APs.

  • •

    z=z′𝑧superscript𝑧′z=z^{\prime} and k=k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k=k^{\prime}. This condition insists that same RRB in the same F-AP is associated with both vertices vk,z,n,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑧𝑛𝑗v_{k,z,n,j} and vk′,z′,n′,j′subscript𝑣superscript𝑘′superscript𝑧′superscript𝑛′superscript𝑗′v_{k^{\prime},z^{\prime},n^{\prime},j^{\prime}}.

Therefore, two vertices vk,z,n,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑧𝑛𝑗v_{k,z,n,j} and vk′,z′,n′,j′subscript𝑣superscript𝑘′superscript𝑧′superscript𝑛′superscript𝑗′v_{k^{\prime},z^{\prime},n^{\prime},j^{\prime}} are adjacent by a conflict edge in ℰℰ\mathcal{E} if they satisfy one of the following CCs.

  • •

    CC1: (n≠n′𝑛superscript𝑛′n\neq n^{\prime} and j≠j′𝑗superscript𝑗′j\neq j^{\prime}) and (k=k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k=k^{\prime} and z≠z′𝑧superscript𝑧′z\neq z^{\prime}), we have 𝙽k>Usubscript𝙽𝑘𝑈\mathtt{N}_{k}>U.

  • •

    CC2: n=n′𝑛superscript𝑛′n=n^{\prime} and/or j=j′𝑗superscript𝑗′j=j^{\prime}.

  • •

    CC3: z=z′𝑧superscript𝑧′z=z^{\prime} and k=k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k=k^{\prime}.

Consider the weight of each vertex vk,z,n,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑧𝑛𝑗v_{k,z,n,j} is defined as w​(v)=Tl​Ck​Dn​α​fk2+pn​𝙳nRk,zn+Tl​Ck​Dj​α​fk2+pj​𝙳jRk,zj𝑤𝑣subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐷𝑛𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑘subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝙳𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑘𝑧subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐷𝑗𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝙳𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑗𝑘𝑧w(v)=T_{l}C_{k}D_{n}\alpha f^{2}_{k}+\frac{p_{n}\mathtt{D}_{n}}{R^{n}_{k,z}}+T_{l}C_{k}D_{j}\alpha f^{2}_{k}+\frac{p_{j}\mathtt{D}_{j}}{R^{j}_{k,z}}. Thus, the vertex’ weight becomes small when the data transmission time from the represented IoT devices is small as well as the local computation time at the represented F-AP is small. This yields to a smart scheduling of IoT devices representing the corresponding vertex with a smaller weight, which in turn minimizes the energy consumption. Therefore, any minimal independent set in NOMA-coordinated graph represents a set of NOMA clusters that satisfies the following criterion: 1) each IoT device in the set is scheduled to only one F-AP and one RRB, 2) each RRB identified by the vertices in a minimal independent set represents a NOMA cluster of two IoT devices, and 3) the total number of scheduled IoT devices at each F-AP is not larger than U𝑈U.

The following theorem characterizes the solution of allocating IoT devices to the RRBs across all F-APs such that the total energy consumption is minimized.

Theorem 1: The IoT device coordinated scheduling problem 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9} is equivalent to MWIS problem over the NOMA-coordinated graph, wherein the weight of a vertex vk,z,n,jsubscript𝑣𝑘𝑧𝑛𝑗v_{k,z,n,j} is given by

w​(v)=α​fk2​Tl​Ck​(Dn+Dj)+pn​𝙳nRk,zn+pj​𝙳jRk,zj.𝑤𝑣𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑘subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝐷𝑗subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝙳𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑘𝑧subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝙳𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑗𝑘𝑧\displaystyle w(v)=\alpha f^{2}_{k}T_{l}C_{k}\left(D_{n}+D_{j}\right)+\frac{p_{n}\mathtt{D}_{n}}{R^{n}_{k,z}}+\frac{p_{j}\mathtt{D}_{j}}{R^{j}_{k,z}}. (27)

The set of scheduled IoT devices to the z𝑧z-th RRB in the k𝑘k-th F-AP is obtained by combining the vertices of the MWIS 𝐈𝐈\mathbf{I} in the NOMA-coordinated graph.

Proof.

This theorem can be proved by demonstrating the following facts. The first fact establishes the equivalency between 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9} and MWIS problems. Specifically, using 𝒢NOMAsubscript𝒢NOMA\mathcal{G}_{\text{NOMA}}, 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9} is similar to MWIS problems. In MWIS problems, two vertices must be nonadjacent in the graph, and similarly, in problem 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9}, two NOMA clusters cannot be allocated with the same RRB or contain at least one IoT device. Afterward, the weight of each vertex is set to be the minimum energy consumption contribution of the corresponding NOMA cluster to the network. Therefore, the MWIS is a feasible solution with the minimum energy consumption, i.e., the MWIS is the feasible solution to 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9}. To finalize the proof, we now prove that the weight of the MWIS is the objective function in 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9} to be minimized. Let 𝐈={v1,v2,⋯,v|𝐈|}𝐈subscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2⋯subscript𝑣𝐈\mathbf{I}=\{v_{1},v_{2},\ \cdots,\,v_{|\mathbf{I}|}\}, v∈𝒢NOMA𝑣subscript𝒢NOMAv\in\mathcal{G}_{\text{NOMA}}. Let a vertex v∈𝒱𝑣𝒱v\in\mathcal{V} is associated with 2-IoT devices NOMA cluster (n,j)𝑛𝑗(n,j). The weight of the MWIS over all the vertices that are representing the corresponding NOMA clusters over all RRBs/F-APs can be written as

w​(𝐈)=∑v∈𝐈w​(v)=∑𝐤∈𝒦∑z∈𝒵(α​fk2​Tl​Ck​(Dn+Dj)+pn​𝙳nRk,zn+pj​𝙳jRk,zj).𝑤𝐈subscript𝑣𝐈𝑤𝑣subscript𝐤𝒦subscript𝑧𝒵𝛼subscriptsuperscript𝑓2𝑘subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝐷𝑗subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝙳𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑛𝑘𝑧subscript𝑝𝑗subscript𝙳𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑗𝑘𝑧\displaystyle\begin{split}w(\mathbf{I})&=\sum\limits_{v\in\mathbf{I}}w(v)\\ &=\sum\limits_{\mathbf{k}\in\mathcal{K}}\sum\limits_{z\in\mathcal{Z}}\left(\alpha f^{2}_{k}T_{l}C_{k}\left(D_{n}+D_{j}\right)+\frac{p_{n}\mathtt{D}_{n}}{R^{n}_{k,z}}+\frac{p_{j}\mathtt{D}_{j}}{R^{j}_{k,z}}\right).\end{split} (28)

Therefore, the problem of minimizing the energy consumption 𝒫9subscript𝒫9\mathcal{P}_{9} is equivalent to the MWIS problem among the minimal sets in the NOMA coordinated graph. ∎

2) Heuristic Solution: MWIS problems are NP-hard problems, where the required complexity of solving these problems optimally requires an exhaustive search of |𝒱|2​.2|𝒱|superscript𝒱2superscript.2𝒱|\mathcal{V}|^{2}.2^{|\mathcal{V}|} complexity where 𝒱𝒱\mathcal{V} is the set of vertices of graph 𝒢NOMAsubscript𝒢NOMA\mathcal{G}_{\text{NOMA}}. However, MWIS problems can be heuristically solved with a reduced complexity of b|𝒱|superscript𝑏𝒱b^{|\mathcal{V}|} where b𝑏b is the complexity constant [36, 37]. Thus, the MWIS problem can be solved effectively using a low-complexity heuristic solution.

Let w​(v)𝑤𝑣w(v) be the raw weight of vertex v𝑣v in the NOMA coordinated graph as expressed in (27). The modified weight w~​(v)~𝑤𝑣\tilde{w}(v) of vertex v𝑣v can be defined as

w~​(v)=w​(v)​∑v′∈𝒱vw​(v′),~𝑤𝑣𝑤𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝑣′subscript𝒱𝑣𝑤superscript𝑣′\tilde{w}(v)=w(v)\sum_{v^{\prime}\in\mathcal{V}_{v}}w({v^{\prime}}), (29)

where 𝒱vsubscript𝒱𝑣\mathcal{V}_{v} is the set of vertices not connected to vertex v𝑣v by transmission conflict edges. The appropriate design of the weights shows that w~vsubscript~𝑤𝑣\tilde{w}_{v} reflects the contribution of the vertex to the network as it has a small raw weight and non-adjacent to a large number of vertices induced by users with small raw weight. The two-phase scenario of IoT device coordinated scheduling and F-AP’s computation frequency allocation is presented in Algorithm 3.

V-C Complexity Analysis

The computational complexity of Algorithm 3 is dominated by the required complexity of generating feasible NOMA clusters and connecting the generated vertices. To generate all the vertices using the low-complexity graph method, a total of 𝒪​(K​Z​(|𝒩k|2))𝒪𝐾𝑍binomialsubscript𝒩𝑘2\mathcal{O}\left(KZ\binom{|\mathcal{N}_{k}|}{2}\right) computational complexity is required. On the other hand, the required complexity of connecting the generating vertices, i.e., the required complexity of finding neighborhood of the generated vertices is 𝒪​((K​Z​(|𝒩k|2))2)𝒪superscript𝐾𝑍binomialsubscript𝒩𝑘22\mathcal{O}\left(\left(KZ\binom{|\mathcal{N}_{k}|}{2}\right)^{2}\right). Therefore, the overall computational complexity of Algorithm 3 is obtained as 𝒪​(N​K​Z+(K​Z​(|𝒩k|2))2)≈𝒪​((K​Z​(|𝒩k|2))2)𝒪𝑁𝐾𝑍superscript𝐾𝑍binomialsubscript𝒩𝑘22𝒪superscript𝐾𝑍binomialsubscript𝒩𝑘22\mathcal{O}\left(NKZ+\left(KZ\binom{|\mathcal{N}_{k}|}{2}\right)^{2}\right)\approx\mathcal{O}\left(\left(KZ\binom{|\mathcal{N}_{k}|}{2}\right)^{2}\right).

VI Numerical Results

VI-A Simulation Setting and Schemes Under Consideration

In our simulations, we consider a hexagonal cell of radius 150015001500 m where F-APs and CS have fixed locations and IoT devices are distributed randomly within the cell. The CS is located at the cell center. The channel model for IoT device-F-AP transmissions follows the standard path-loss model, which consists of three components: 1) path-loss of 128.1+37.6​log10⁡(dis.[km])128.137.6subscript10dis.[km]128.1+37.6\log_{10}(\text{dis.[km]}); 2) log-normal shadowing with 444 dB standard deviation; and 3) Rayleigh channel fading with zero-mean and unit variance. The noise power, F-AP’s power, and maximum’ IoT device power are assumed to be −174174-174 dBm/Hz and qk=pmax=3subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑝max3q_{k}=p_{\text{max}}=3 W, respectively [25]. The weighting factor V𝑉V is set to 0.30.30.3. The total number of global and local FL iterations are calculated as Tg=2​β2(2​ϑ−β​η)​ϑ​η​ln⁡(1/ϵg)subscript𝑇𝑔2superscript𝛽22italic-ϑ𝛽𝜂italic-ϑ𝜂1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔T_{g}=\frac{2\beta^{2}}{(2\vartheta-\beta\eta)\vartheta\eta}\ln(1/\epsilon_{g}), Tl=2(2−δ​β)​δ​ϑ​ln⁡(1/ϵl)subscript𝑇𝑙22𝛿𝛽𝛿italic-ϑ1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙T_{l}=\frac{2}{(2-\delta\beta)\delta\vartheta}\ln(1/\epsilon_{l}), respectively, with β=4,η=1/3,δ=1/4,ϑ=2,ϵg=ϵl=10−3formulae-sequence𝛽4formulae-sequence𝜂13formulae-sequence𝛿14formulae-sequenceitalic-ϑ2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙superscript103\beta=4,\eta=1/3,\delta=1/4,\vartheta=2,\epsilon_{g}=\epsilon_{l}=10^{-3} [21]. The FL time threshold Tqsubscript𝑇𝑞T_{q} is 111 second [21]. The bandwidth of each RRB is 202020 MHz. Unless otherwise stated, we set the numbers of F-APs and RRBs to 999 and 444, respectively. The fronthaul capacity Rf​hsubscript𝑅𝑓ℎR_{fh} is set to 150 Mbit/s. For each IoT device and each F-AP, the number of data samples Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} is randomly chosen from 800800800 to 100010001000. Other parameters are summarized in Table I. To assess the performance of our proposed scenarios, we simulate various scenarios with different number of IoT devices N𝑁N, data size 𝙳nsubscript𝙳𝑛\mathtt{D}_{n}, number of RRBs Z𝑍Z, number of data samples Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n}, computation frequency allocation fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}, fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k}, and parameter data size. For the sake of comparison, our proposed schemes are compared with the following baseline schemes.

  • •

    Power-only: This scheme minimizes the energy consumption by optimizing the power level of IoT devices and fixing the computation frequency allocation to its maximum value.

  • •

    Computation frequency-only: This scheme, denoted by CPU-only, minimizes the energy consumption by optimizing the computation frequency allocation and fixing the power level to its maximum value.

  • •

    Fixed: This scheme employs random IoT device scheduling and fixes both the computation frequency allocation and transmission power to their maximum values.

VI-B Simulation Results and Discussions

We adopt two performance metrics as follows: (i) the energy consumption that represents the objective in 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} for the IoT device local learning scenario and 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} for the F-AP local learning scenario, and (ii) the FL time as expressed in (II-B).

1) Consumption energy performance: In Figs. 4-a and 4-b, we plot the energy consumption versus the number of IoT devices for the first and second scenarios, respectively. Our proposed schemes have the following two attributes. First, they judiciously schedule IoT devices to F-APs/RRBs, adapt the transmission rate of each IoT device, and optimize the transmission power of each IoT device. Second, our proposed schemes efficiently optimize the computation frequency allocation of IoT devices and F-APs. Leveraging these two attributes, our proposed schemes significantly reduce the energy consumption compared to the benchmark schemes, as depicted from both Figs. 4-a and 4-b. In particular, the power-only scheme selects the maximum computation frequency allocation for each IoT device and each F-AP. Consequently, the power-only scheme results in higher energy consumption for local learning, and it increases the energy consumption of the system in both scenarios. The CPU-only scheme ignores the power optimization that leads to more interference among the IoT devices and increased offloading transmission time. As a result, the CPU-only scheme leads to a high energy consumption. Finally, the fixed scheme has the most energy consumption because it chooses the maximum CPU frequency and transmission power. Accordingly, from an energy consumption perspective, it is inefficient to offload data to F-APs while ignoring the power allocation and employing random IoT device scheduling to F-APs/RRBs.

In Figs. 4-a and 4-b, we plot the energy consumption versus the data size 𝙳nsubscript𝙳𝑛\mathtt{D}_{n} for the first and second scenarios, respectively. When the data size is small (around 111 Kbit), both proposed schemes work superior in terms of minimizing the energy consumption. When the data size is nearly 101010 Mbit, the energy consumption performance of our proposed first scheme does not change much and has a performance of 333 J. This is becasue the IoT devices perform local learning on the data and offload the local learning parameters only. However, when the data size changes from 111 Kbit to 101010 Mbit, the energy consumption performance of the proposed second scheme changes form 111 J to around 303303303 J. Therefore, our proposed second scheme consumes more energy when the data size increases. Accordingly, from an energy consumption perspective, learning at the IoT devices as in the first proposed scenario is more efficient, especially for large numbers of IoT devices and large data sizes.

In Figs. 6-a and 6-b, we show the energy consumption versus the number of data samples Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} for the first and second scenarios, respectively. The number of data samples affects the CPU-related energy consumption. Similar to our discussions for Fig. 4, the CPU-only and fixed schemes severely degrades the energy consumption performance. Specifically, the energy consumption of the fixed scheme is increased with the number of data samples. However, the energy consumption of the power-only and our proposed schemes do not significantly change, e.g., see Fig. 6-(a). Since the energy consumption in the second scenario is dominated by data offloading to F-APs, both CPU-only and fixed schemes consume high energy as can be seen from Fig. 6-(b). Using the optimized resource allocations, our proposed schemes incur the least energy consumption for both small and large data samples.

In Figs. 6-a and 6-b, we plot the energy consumption versus the number of RRBs Z𝑍Z for the first and second scenarios, respectively. As can be seen, the consumed energy of all schemes are increased with the increase in the number of RRBs. This is due to the fact that as the number of RRBs increases, more IoT devices are scheduled, which in turn increases the energy consumption. Specifically, when Z=1𝑍1Z=1, the maximum number of accommodated IoT devices by the F-APs is 2​Z​K=2×1×9=182𝑍𝐾219182ZK=2\times 1\times 9=18, thus the consumed energy of all schemes is low. As the number of RRBs is increased, the energy consumption of all the schemes is increased. This can be explained by the fact that when the number of RRBs goes beyond 222, no more IoT devices can be accommodated. Thus, the consumed energy of all schemes do not change much. For a fair comparison, we consider that all the schemes serve the same set of IoT devices in the available RRBs of a given F-AP. The proposed schemes, however, benefit from optimizing the transmit power and computation frequency allocation. Essentially, the proposed schemes achieve reduced energy consumption compared to the benchmark schemes.

In Figs. 8-a and 8-a , we show the energy consumption versus the number of CPU cycles for the first and second scenarios, respectively. The number of CPU cycles ranges from 2×1072superscript1072\times 10^{7} to 10×10710superscript10710\times 10^{7} in Fig. 8-(a) and from 2×1092superscript1092\times 10^{9} to 10×10910superscript10910\times 10^{9} in Fig. 8-(b). The number of CPU cycles determines the energy consumption. Hence, the energy consumption of both fixed and power-only schemes, that fix the computation frequency allocation at the highest value, is considerably increased with the increasing number of computation cycles. On the other hand, the energy consumption of both CPU-only and proposed schemes with adjustable CPU frequencies do not change much as shown in Figs. 8-a and 8-b. As expected, using both transmit power and computation frequency allocation, our proposed schemes incur the least energy consumption for both small and large numbers of CPU cycles.

2) FL time performance: In Fig. 8, Fig. 10, and Fig. 10, we plot the federated learning time versus: (a) number of IoT devices N𝑁N, (b) number of data samples Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n}, and (c) parameter data size dnsubscript𝑑𝑛d_{n}, respectively. First, it is clear that the FL time depends on the transmission time and the computation learning time of IoT devices. Since the local learning parameters have small size, the transmission time for offloading such parameters to F-APs/CS requires smaller portion of the overall FL time compared with the computation training time. Consequently, the FL time is dominated by the computation training time. As can be seen from Figs. 8, 10, 10, fixed scheme, that chooses the maximum CPU frequency, effectively minimizes the FL time at the cost of consuming the most energy as shown in Fig. 4 to Fig. 8. Our proposed first scheme that considers IoT device local learning, denoted by proposed, adjusts the CPU frequency and power transmissions so that it effectively minimizes the consumed energy within the FL time of 111 second. In Figs. 8, 10, the FL time of all algorithms does not change much with the number of IoT devices and local parameter size. This is because the FL time is mainly controlled by the longest local training time of one IoT device, which does not significantly change when the number of IoT device and the local parameter size are increased.

Finally, we provide some observations from our presented simulation results as follows. First, although the fixed scheme performs fairly well in terms of reducing the FL time, it exhibits a poor energy consumption performance, which is impractical. Thus, it only serves as a benchmark scheme in this work. Second, it is advantageous to optimize the computation frequency allocation of the IoT devices and the F-APs as in the CPU-only scheme. However, it is inefficient to ignore the power optimization that significantly impacts the energy consumption of the system. Third, the power-only scheme works well in terms if reducing the energy consumption; however, its performance is degraded since it uses the maximum CPU of each IoT and each F-AP. Fourth, our proposed schemes strike a balance between the aforementioned aspects by judiciously scheduling IoT devices to F-APs/RRBs, adapting the transmission rate of each IoT device, and optimizing the transmission power of each IoT device. Furthermore, our proposed schemes efficiently optimize the computation frequency allocation of IoT devices and F-APs. Finally, as the data size increases, the energy consumption performance of the second proposed scheme degrades. This is because as the data size increases, the transmission time for offloading IoT devices’ data to F-APs is significantly increased. Thus, the energy efficiency of our proposed first scheme becomes more pronounced compared to our second proposed scheme.

VII Conclusion

In this paper, we investigated the resource allocation strategy to minimize the energy consumption for performing FL in an integrated FCC-enabled IoT network subject to FL time constraint. Specifically, we considered two scenarios for training the local models, and for both scenarios, we proposed joint optimization of computation frequency allocation, IoT device scheduling, and transmission power control of network edge devices. Leveraging graph theory, we proposed efficient iterative schemes. The presented numerical results revealed that the proposed schemes substantially reduce the energy consumption compared to the baseline solutions, at the cost of small increase of FL learning time. The presented simulation results interestingly revealed that for a large number of IoT devices and large data sizes, it is more energy efficient to train the local models at the IoT devices instead of the F-APs.
